title: India editors warn 'fake news' proposal akin to censorship
summary: A prominent Indian journalist organization has called on the government to reject proposed changes to IT rules that would allow fact-checking of social media content, arguing such measures would amount to censorship of the press.
content:
NEW DELHI - A major Indian journalist group urged the government to reject a proposal to police fake news on social media, saying such a change to the country's information-technology rules would be akin to censorship.

The Editors Guild of India expressed serious concerns about amendments that would require social media companies to take down content marked as "fake" by authorities. The group warned this could have a chilling effect on press freedom and independent journalism.

The proposed changes would give government fact-checkers broad powers to flag content as false without providing clear guidelines or an appeals process. Media organizations fear this could be misused to suppress legitimate news coverage and criticism of official policies.

The move comes amid growing global debate about how to combat misinformation while protecting free speech rights.
